Hunan Dongjiang Lake Environmental Protection and 
Integrated Utilization Project (Concept Paper PRC 47070) 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  During  the  country  programming  mission  held  in  Manila  in  November  2012,  the 
government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to assist the governments of Hunan Province and Zixing City in preparing the Hunan 
Dongjiang  Lake  Environmental  Protection  and  Integrated  Utilization  Project.  The  project  is 
included in ADB’s lending program for 2015 standby under the country operations business 
plan, 2013–2015 for the PRC. A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required to 
undertake due diligence in technical, safeguards, economic and financial, and poverty and 
social areas. The PPTA will help ensure compliance with ADB’s requirements and incorporation 
of international best practices in the project design. 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The  major  output  of  the  PPTA  will  be  a  project  design  which  responds  to  the 
government’s needs and fulfill ADB’s requirements. Specifically, the outputs include (i) a sector 
assessment; (ii) financial management and procurement capacity assessments; (iii) stakeholder 
analysis  and  project  design  and  monitoring  framework  (DMF);  (iv)  project  technical, 
environmental, economic, financial, and social viability appraisals; (v) a gender action plan and 
a social action plan; (vi) a resettlement plan; (vii) an environmental impact assessment and an 
environmental management plan; (viii) project implementation schedule and a procurement 
plan; and (ix) a project administration manual. The key outputs and activities are summarized in 
Table A4.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent, of which $600,000 equivalent will 
be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other 
sources); and $200,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust 
Fund1 under the Water Financing Partnership Facility administered by ADB. The cofinancier 
funds will be utilized on a front-loaded basis. The government will provide in-kind contributions 
(20% of the total PPTA cost), including counterpart staff remuneration, office accommodation, 
transportation to the project sites, access to communications and data, and other administrative 
support. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  It  is  expected  that  15  person-months  (pm)  of  international  and  47  pm  of  national 
consultants are required. The consultants will support the executing and implementing agencies 
in completing the project feasibility studies and safeguard documents to a standard consistent 
with the requirements of ADB and the government. The consultants will also provide start-up 
project implementation support to the executing and implementing agencies. ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) will be applied in recruiting 
consultants. A consulting firm will be engaged using quality- and cost-based selection method 
with quality and cost ratio of 80:20. Table A4.3 provides details of the required expertise. The 
outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 5–20 (detailed terms 
of reference presented as a separate attachment).

5.  Water environmental management specialist/team leader (international, 6 pm), and 
wastewater management specialist/deputy team leader (national, 6 pm). The specialists will 
have a master degree or above in water environmental management, wastewater management, 
or other related fields. They shall have 10 years of work experience in project development and 
implementation, and familiar with ADB’s project processing requirements. The team leader will 
have overall responsibility for the PPTA coordination and implementation, and the quality of all 
PPTA  outputs.  Specifically,  the  specialists  will  (i)  prepare  a  sector  assessment  report;  (ii) 
conduct stakeholder analyses, and develop the project DMF; (iii) review the overall project 
design;  (iv)  recommend  a  project  performance  management  system;  (v)  prepare  the 
implementation schedule and the detailed implementation arrangements; (vi) analyze lessons 
learned from the previous projects financed by ADB, other development partners, and the 
government; and incorporate them in the project design; (vii) prepare inception, interim, draft 
final, and final reports; (viii) project scenarios of future water quality in the absence of the 
project; and (ix) organize and implement training for the executing and implementing agencies.

Appendix 4  4 
 
6.  Economics  and  finance  specialists  (international,  3  pm;  national  environmental 
economist, 3 pm; and national financial analyst, 2 pm). The specialists will have a master 
degree or above in economics or finance, and 7 years of work experience in economic and 
financial analyses of ADB- or World Bank-financed projects. The specialists will (i) review and 
prepare project cost estimates and financing plan; (ii) conduct project economic and financial 
analyses, covering demand forecast, least-economic cost analysis, economic and financial cost-
and-benefit analysis, economic and financial internal rates of return, sensitivity analysis, and 
benefit distributional analysis; (iii) conduct analysis on the wastewater tariffs covering policies 
and regulations, existing structures, cost-recovery tariff setting, cross-region comparison, and 
other related issues; (iv) conduct willingness-to-pay and affordability analysis; and (v) review the 
fund flow, loan repayment, and disbursement arrangements. 
7.  Environment specialists (international, 3 pm; national, 3 pm). The specialists will have 
a  master  degree  or  above  in  environmental  studies  and  10  years  of  work  experience  in 
environmental  assessment.  The  specialists  will  (i)  review  draft  domestic  environmental 
safeguard  reports,  and  obtain  any  additional  information  needed  to  comply  with  ADB’s 
requirements; (ii) assess possible environmental impacts of each subproject, and prepare a 
consolidated environmental impact assessment report and an environmental management plan 
to  meet  ADB’s  requirements,  including  description  of  each  mitigation  measure  and  cost 
estimates, environmental monitoring plan, institutional arrangements, implementation schedule, 
and public consultations; (iii) coordinate with the social development plans for the inputs to be 
covered in the consolidated environmental assessment, including livelihood issues related to 
environment; and (iv) assess initial climate change impacts, and recommend options on how to 
cope with climate change. 
8.  Social development and resettlement specialist (international, 3 pm). The specialist 
will have a master degree or equivalent qualification in social sciences and/or development 
studies, and at least 7 years of work experience in social development, with proven experience 
in social safeguards and/or resettlement planning and implementation. Extensive experience in 
social assessment, poverty analysis, and gender analysis is essential, as is familiarity with 
qualitative and quantitative methodology. The consultants should have good knowledge on rural 
poverty and rural–urban inequality issues in the PRC, including poverty trends, geographical 
and/or regional distribution of the poor, and characteristics of typical poor households in the 
rural  PRC.  Knowledge  of  the  Chinese  language  will  be  an  asset.  Recent  experience  in 
preparing resettlement plans and social analysis for ADB-financed projects, and familiarity with 
the  ADB  policies  and guidelines  on  safeguards, resettlement,  poverty  and  social  analysis, 
gender mainstreaming, and consultation and participation will be highly regarded. The specialist 
will lead the national resettlement and social development specialists to accomplish the tasks 
described in paras. 9 and 10 following the sections of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) 
and  other  ADB  policies  regarding  poverty  and  social  analysis,  gender,  consultation  and 
participation, etc. The specialist will be responsible for coordinating social development and 
social safeguard requirements with the work of the other PPTA team members. 
9.  Social development specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will have at least a 
master’s degree in a social science or a relevant field, and at least 7 years of experience 
working on social development, preferably on rural development and water resource projects 
financed by ADB or the World Bank group. Extensive experience in social assessment, poverty 
analysis, and gender analysis is essential, as is familiarity with qualitative and quantitative 
methodology. The specialist will support the international social development and resettlement 
specialist to conduct a poverty and social analysis; prepare social development documents; and 
prepare social surveys and other research to assess poverty, gender, labor, and other social

5  Appendix 4 
 
dimensions, with the objective of preparing design elements that will make the project socially 
and economically inclusive in the sense that the poor, vulnerable, and excluded households will 
benefit from the project; and that will contribute to increased gender equity. The specialist will 
assess whether safeguard requirements 3 in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) will be 
triggered; and if triggered, will assist in preparing an ethnic minority development plan. 
10.  Resettlement specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will have a master’s degree or 
equivalent qualification in a field relevant to social safeguards, and at least 7 years of work 
experience in resettlement in internationally financed projects with rural land acquisition impact. 
The specialist will have extensive experience in involuntary resettlement safeguard planning 
documents,  and  in-depth  knowledge  of  current  PRC  legislation  and  policy  regarding  land 
acquisition,  land  tenure  consolidation,  and  land  transfer.  The  specialist  will  support  the 
international social development and resettlement specialist to (i) collect data on land use in 
project impact areas and assess whether the project will cause any resettlement impacts; (ii) 
review past, present, and future social impacts, conduct consultation to determine the economic 
and sociocultural conditions of potentially affected persons; (iii) confirm and verify presence or 
absence of persons who may be differentially or disproportionately affected by the project; and 
(iv) assist the implementing agency in preparing a resettlement plan; and (v) confirm and verify 
presence  or  absence  of complaints  in  relation  to  the  project  and  selected  sites,  etc. The 
specialist will be responsible to coordinate social safeguard requirements with the work of the 
other national PPTA team members.  
11.  Climate change and water resources management specialist (national, 4 pm). The 
specialist  will  have  (i)  a  graduate  degree  or  equivalent  experience  in  water  resources 
management, hydrology, water engineering, ecology, or environment, or equivalent; (ii) at least 
10 years of work experience in integrated water resources management and climate change; 
(iii) demonstrated expertise in evaluating potential impacts of climate change on water security 
and making recommendations for adaptation in the water sector; and (iv) proficiency in spoken 
and written English. Specifically, the specialist will (i) review the water resources development 
and conservation plans in the project area; (ii) assist in sector assessment; (iii) conduct water 
demand and water balance analyses, including consideration of climate variability and changes; 
(iv) assess climate change impacts and model climate projections; (v) assess climate change 
risks; and (vi) identify opportunities for climate proofing, adaptation, and mitigation actions 
and/or activities to be incorporated in the project design. 
12.  Financial management specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have a degree in 
financial management and at least 7 years of work experience in project financial management 
assessment. The specialist will (i) conduct a financial management assessment of the executing 
and  implementing  agencies;  (ii)  assess  their  policies  and  capacity  for  financial  and 
disbursement management; (iii) review existing procedures for disbursement, funds flow, and 
approvals; and recommend streamlined procedures for contracting and disbursement under the 
project, and internal control and audits; (iv) review onlending arrangements; and (v) assist in 
financial projections and analyses.  
13.  Institutional and capacity development specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist 
should have a degree in management or related field, and at least 7 years of work experience 
with ADB or other externally funded projects. Experience with ADB- or World Bank-financed 
projects  in  the  water  resources  management  and  environment  sectors  is  expected.  The 
specialist will (i) assess the institutional settings for environmental and lake management; (ii) 
review, assess, and prepare the institutional impacts of the project following ADB guidelines; (iii) 
assess the existing management for water resources protection and wetland management in

the project area and their capacity, and propose institutional and capacity development plans to 
be included in the project; and (iv) recommend measures for improving performance. 
14.  Project management and procurement specialist (national, 4 pm). The specialist will 
have a degree in engineering and at least 7 years of work experience in project management, 
and procurement and consulting services. The specialist will (i) conduct procurement capacity 
assessment  for  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  undertake  procurement  and 
consultant recruitments envisaged under the project; (ii) prepare a procurement plan; (iii) assess 
the  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  for  project  implementation,  and 
prepare training proposals to be included under the project; (iv) provide necessary trainings on 
project management, procurement, and consulting services; and (v) assist in developing the 
DMF and performance targets. 
15.  Solid waste management specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have a degree 
in environment or relevant field, and at least 7 years of work experience in waste treatment and 
environmental management. The specialist will (i) review the relevant government policy and 
plans regarding solid waste treatment in Zixing City; (ii) assist in assessing the pollution status 
in Dongjiang Lake catchment; and (iii) review the measures of solid waste management, and 
recommend measures for improvement under the project to reduce water pollution. 
16.  Nonpoint source pollution management specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist 
will have a degree in environment or relevant field, and at least 7 years of work experience in 
nonpoint source pollution management and environmental management. The specialist will (i) 
review  the  relevant  government  policy  and  plans  regarding  nonpoint  source  pollution 
management; (ii) assess nonpoint sources pollution status; and (iii) review the measures of 
managing  nonpoint  source  pollution,  and  propose  measures  for  mitigating  and  reducing 
nonpoint source pollution under the project. 
17.  Soil conservation and vegetation specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have 
a master degree or above in botany, or environment or other relevant field, and at least 10 years 
of  work  experience  in  soil  conservation,  re-vegetation,  restoration,  and  rehabilitation  of 
degraded landscape. The specialist will (i) review the relevant government policy and plans 
regarding soil conservation and reforestation; (ii) assess the soil conservation and reforestation 
programs and plans; and (iii) review the proposed activities to be included in the project, and 
provide recommendations for improvement. 
18.  Biodiversity and wetland management specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will 
have a master degree or above in ecology or biodiversity or other relevant fields, and at least 10 
years of work experience in wetland rehabilitation and management. The specialist will (i) 
review the relevant government policy and plans relating to wetland management; (ii) assess 
wetland rehabilitation programs and plans; and (iii) review the proposed wetland rehabilitation 
interventions to be included in the project, and provide recommendations for improvement. 
19.  Eco-compensation specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will have a degree in 
environment or relevant field, and at least 7 years of work experience in eco-compensation and 
payment for environmental services. The specialist will (i) review the relevant government policy 
and plans regarding eco-compensation; (ii) assess the value of the ecosystem of Dongjiang 
Lake; (iii) review the proposed activities under the project, and provide recommendations for 
improvement;  and  (iv)  recommend  policy  reforms,  and  propose  several  eco-compensation 
options for government to further take actions.

7  Appendix 4 
 
20.  Water supply specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialists will have a degree in water 
supply or other related fields; 10 years of work experience in water supply and water resources 
management  project  development  and  implementation;  and  familiar  with  ADB’s  project 
processing requirements. The specialists will (i) assist in preparing a sector assessment report, 
and identify issues and constraints of water supply in the project area; (ii) assess water demand 
forecasts and the feasibility of the water supply systems to be developed under the project, and 
propose  recommendations  for  improving  project  design;  (iii)  estimate  operation  and 
maintenance  costs  of  the  project,  including  the  recurrent  cost  of  implementing  social  and 
environmental safeguards; and (iv) assist in preparing a procurement plan and the project 
implementation schedule. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The Zixing city government will be the executing agency responsible for overall planning 
and management of project. A project leading group, chaired by the mayor of the Zixing city 
government, has established and will ensure coordination across sectors; and provide guidance 
to the PPTA implementation, project preparation, and implementation. A project management 
office, headed by the deputy director of the Zixing City Development and Reform Bureau, has 
also  been  formed  to  be  responsible  for  daily  coordination  of  the  PPTA  implementation, 
preparation, and implementation of the project. In Chenzhou Municipality, a project leading 
group  will  be  established  to  guide,  coordinate,  and  support  project  preparation  and 
implementation. The Hunan Provincial Development and Reform Commission and the Hunan 
Provincial Finance Department will provide overall guidance, coordination, and supervision. The 
equipment will be procured by the consulting firm following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2013, as amended from time to time) and will be handed over to the executing agency upon 
completion of the PPTA. The training and workshop funds will be administered through the 
consultants. The disbursement will be done following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
22.  The PPTA will be implemented in about 18 months from 15 July 2014 to 31 December 
2015. The proposed PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
